posts.description: DC friends! This coming Tuesday, April 25, I'll join fellow photographer @stephsinclairpix and @natgeo Editor-In-Chief Susan Goldberg for a conversation on #gender at the National Geographic Museum in Washington, DC. Stephanie and I will each present elements of our respective bodies of work before discussing them with Susan and the audience. It'll be an interesting evening for sure. Link to full details and tickets in bio. Hope to see some of you there! #DC #gender #boyhood #masculinity #genderrevolution #events

This evening I'll be in conversation about my work with Jon Western, Dean of Faculty of Mount Holyoke College, at the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum. We'll talk chat about armed conflict, masculinity, art and visual journalism. The event is free and open to the public. Drop by if you're in the area. #MHC #museum #art #mountholyokecollege #photography #photographer

A wonderful afternoon at the @clarkart Institute in Williamstown, Massachusetts. This is one of the finest and most unassuming presentations of art that I've ever seen. To reach the Institute, one drives through the scenic and rural hills of the #berkshires where one might not expect to discover this world class collection. A beautiful research center and library to boot! Here, an extraordinary picture by Sir Lawrence Alma-Tadema entitled The Women of Amphissa. A must see if you find yourself in this part of the world. #massachusetts #art #museum #berkshires
The @abbrewery in Easthampton, MA, feels like you're drinking craft beers in your living room--if you had a really cool living room. Amazing. #newengland #MA #westernmass #brewery

The large boulders behind my friend, Joe, make up what's known as King Phillips Cave in the town of Norton, #Massachusetts. King Phillip's War was a campaign of fierce, cyclical violence that occurred between 1675 and 1676 between English settlers and the Wampanoag, Nipmuck and Narragansett Indians. It is widely regarded as the largest loss of life (per capita) in the history of the United States and a key event in the formation of colonial identity in the territories. I grew up in Massachusetts and learned virtually nothing about it in our public schools. It felt deeply disconcerting to cross the street from Joe's house, past a string of newly-constructed million-dollar homes, to this small protected site. As we explored the rock formations and thought about what they signified, a man ran a snow blower on the driveway of his palatial home. During my visiting professorship at Mount Holyoke College, I've been reading an incredible book about King Phillip's War by historian Jill Lepore. An important book for all. #MA #nativeamerican #wanpanoag #kingphilipswar #winter #newengland

My father, Norman, sits at the head of the table during his retirement party. He's characteristically more interested in his soup than in conversation üòâ. He's retiring after a 35-year stint as the art conservator at the @princeton_university Art Museum. Beyond the Princeton museum, he has more than 50 years of experience in the field of art conservation. It's remarkable to consider. I drove from Massachusetts to New Jersey for the night to attend the celebration of his contribution. Time marches on. What a bitter sweet affair. #dad #retirement

For the first time in many years, my mother and I celebrated our birthdays together. They fall a week apart in the depths of winter and are therefore often quiet affairs. This year, we enjoyed a lovely dinner prepared by my sister, Irene, exchanged a few, small gifts and took advantage of the opportunity to be together. One of the most wonderful things about teaching at Mount Holyoke College this semester is its proximity to my family in eastern Massachusetts. Coming home so often makes me painfully aware of how much I miss when I'm so far away. I'm very grateful to have this time together. #family #USA #birthdays #winter

The winters in Massachusetts are as tough as I remember--but sledding helps a little. We've had two significant snow storms over the last week and they've left me thinking. I'm immersed in literature about the human propensity to band together in order to confront challenges. Many scholars argue that modern humans have been naturally selected for our ability to cooperate in the face of threats; that those who failed to participate died and therefore left fewer descendants. While a snowstorm in the modern era poses nominal risk, I can't help but feel that it ignites something primordial within us. In particular, I think it does something to men, who suddenly feel needed. A snowstorm creates a small window in which male physical strength becomes an valuable commodity. They can more easily shovel wet heavy snow, push out vehicles and execute other tasks in which strength is an asset. As much as we claim to hate these storms, I think they evoke something important and meaningful within us. #massachusetts #USA #snow #winteriscoming #winter #ipswich

After a couple of crazy and rather distressing days, I retreated to the ocean front in Lynn, Massachusetts, near where I grew up. No phone. No distractions. Just waves crashing against the sea wall and brisk winter air. "Go placidly amid the noise and the haste, and remember what peace there may be in silence." Time to focus on actual, constructive contributions. #Lynn #Massachusetts #dailylife #ocean #water
Tens of thousands on Boston Common in support of women's rights. A lively, affirming and inclusive crowd. #womensmarch #boston #trump #equality

Andres Franklin (L) and Noah King (R), both rising sophomores at Saint Benedicts Prep School, rest in the grass during school's annual wilderness expedition. Each year, as an enshrined rite of passage, the freshman class must complete a grueling five-day, 55-mile hike along the Appalachian Trail. ‚ÄúThe experience teaches kids to help one another,‚Äù explains Edwin Leahy, the school‚Äôs headmaster. ‚ÄúIt creates a sense of community that is frequently not taught to young men. It‚Äôs this rugged individualism that gets communicated.‚Äù The all boys‚Äô prep school in Newark, New Jersey aims to impart an emotionally aware and expressive form of masculine identity. ‚ÄúIf young guys don‚Äôt find constructive means of expression, their anger either gets expressed outwardly in poor behavior or inward as self destruction,‚Äù Leahy adds. #boyhood #manhood #masculinity #gender #hiking #SBP #Saintbenedicts #newjersey #natgeo

Students from Saint Benedict's Prep laugh and joke around a campfire during the school's annual backpacking trip on the Appalachian Trail. In addition to being an important challenge and rite of passage at the school, it builds powerful camaraderie among the participating students. The days on the trail are grueling, sometimes covering upwards of fifteen miles. It's a physical and metal challenge that prompts a variety responses. At night, despite exhaustion, youthful energy prevails and the boys relax, recover and rejoice in their accomplishments. Their confidence builds with each passing day. #boyhood #manhood #masculinity #genderrevolution #gender #saintbenedicts #sbp #newjersey #hiking #outdoors #fire #comradarie

I walked often with Victor Rivera--pictured here at the front of the line. Victor is a soft-spoken student who, in some ways, reminded me of myself at his age.  The journey was hard on Victor who, by the second night, hobbled severely about the campsite. Despite the physical strain, Victor was determined not only to complete the journey but also to extract meaning from it. ‚ÄúFor me, I get angry really quickly,‚Äù he explains along a ridgeline on the penultimate day. ‚ÄúBut I have not gotten angry with any of my group members during this whole trail. I think it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm asking for help,‚Äù he adds. #masculinity #boyhood #gender #manhood #newjersey #newark #Saintbenedicts #SBP #natgeo #genderrevolution

And so, pondering my own journey decades before, I followed the boys of Saint Benedict's Prep into the woods. For many, it was a first foray into the wilderness and a stark departure from the urban centers of their upbringing. Griping and discomfort defined the initial days as they adjusted to the absence of showers, arduous hikes, and food‚Äîprepared by the boys themselves‚Äîthat left something to be desired. They razzed and cajoled one another and, quite quickly, structures of leadership and cooperation emerged. Resistance gave way to a quiet and collective determination. #boyhood #gender #masculinity #manhood #natgeo #genderrevolution #saintbenedicts #newjersey #sbp

A group of students from Saint Benedict's Prep School in Newark, New Jersey head out on the Appalachian Trail. The journey, which serves as an important rite of passage as students pass from their freshman to sophomore year, consists of a grueling, 55 mile hike over the course of five days. It was on a similar but longer excursion that I found some redemption from the troubles that defined my own adolescent years. It was there, in rural Maine, away from the noise and the haste, that the social pressures of masculine performance ebbed and I found room to reengage with myself. It gave me room to consider the choices I'd made and the emotional aspects of my misbehavior. ‚ÄúThe backpacking trip is huge here,‚Äù Father Edwin explains. ‚ÄúIt teaches kids of help one another and creates a sense of community that is frequently not taught to young men. It‚Äôs this rugged individualism that gets communicated.‚Äù #boyhood #masculinity #gender #outdoors #discovery #genderrevolution #teens #saintbenedicts #sbp

Today, I am honored to take over the @national_gallery Instagram account! In support of the Gallery's ongoing exhibition #BeyondCaravaggio, I'm sharing work that was influenced by the Italian master painter.  I was pleased to collaborate with Letizia Treves, head of the Gallery's Curatorial Department and curator of Beyond Caravaggio, to contextualize the images. I'll return to posting photos from my @natgeo project on boyhood and masculinity starting tomorrow. ____________________

Exhausted from a long day in the fields of rural Ivory Coast, a man sits resigned in his doorway. Brimming with childhood exuberance, his young neighbor does a handstand against their shared wall. The aesthetics of the picture were influenced by the master painter, Caravaggio. Letizia Treves, the curator of #BeyondCaravaggio, ruminates on the painter‚Äôs particular influence in the image, ‚ÄúThe strong directional light in this picture, silhouetting the edge of the doorway and window behind, remind me of Caravaggio‚Äôs Calling of St Matthew in the Contarelli Chapel, San Luigi dei Francesi (Rome) ‚Äì Caravaggio‚Äôs first major public commission. The way the light catches the outstretched arm and hand of the seated man also recalls Caravaggio‚Äôs illumination of Christ‚Äôs important gesture in the painting ‚Äì his outstretched arm calling Saint Matthew to follow him.‚Äù

Boys at Saint Benedict‚Äôs Prep in Newark participate in physical exercises in preparation for the backpacking expedition, a grueling, five-day, 55-mile trek through the Appalachian Mountains. The trip is a formative rite of passage for the school's rising sophomore class. 
__________________________________________ 
Saint Benedict‚Äôs emphasis on boys attaining emotional awareness struck a chord with me‚Äînow a man of 34 who spent most of my adolescent and teen years flirting with serious social dysfunction. My parents split when I was a child and their separation, however minor in the scheme of human suffering, upended my emotional world. Their separation occurred as I was starting to understand the social parameters of my nascent masculine identity. Like most boys, I quickly learned that tears and other expressions of sorrow were met with coercive social ridicule. Despite its destructive potential, anger seemed the only acceptable form of masculine emotional expression. And so, within the confines of my prescribed gender, I disguised my sadness as rage and soon found myself on the edge of destruction. Fistfights, suspensions and other forms of social malady defined my adolescent and teen years. #men #boys #masculinity #manhood #gender #genderrevolution #saintbenedicts #SBP #NewJersey #NJ #newark #ritesofpassage
